The synthesis of hyperbranched ethylene oligomers by nickel catalysts with oxazole structure Nan Nie a 1 Yizhan Wang a 1 Chen Tan b ⁎ Min Chen b ⁎ Dan Peng a ⁎ a CAS Key Laboratory of Soft Matter Chemistry, Department of Polymer Science and Engineering, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei National Laboratory for Physical Sciences at the Microscale, Hefei 230026, China CAS Key Laboratory of Soft Matter Chemistry Department of Polymer Science and Engineering University of Science and Technology of China Hefei National Laboratory for Physical Sciences at the Microscale Hefei 230026 China CAS Key Laboratory of Soft Matter Chemistry, Department of Polymer Science and Engineering, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei National Laboratory for Physical Sciences at the Microscale, Hefei 230026, China b Institutes of Physical Science and Information Technology, Anhui University, Hefei, Anhui 230601, China Institutes of Physical Science and Information Technology Anhui University Hefei Anhui 230601 China Institutes of Physical Science and Information Technology, Anhui University, Hefei, Anhui 230601, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Graphical abstract Since the discovery of Shell-Higher-Olefin-Process (SHOP), ethylene oligomerization has been one of the most significant processes of homogenous transition-metal catalysts. And the structure designing of catalysts is always the key issue for ethylene oligomerization. In this contribution, a series of oxazole-based nickel complexes were synthesized to prepare the hyperbranched ethylene oligomers. The catalytic performance could be modulated by adjusting the electronic and steric effects of the nickel catalysts. And DFT calculations were also performed to reveal the electronic and steric effects of the ligand structures. Specially, these nickel complexes could catalyze the copolymerization of ethylene and polar monomers (6-chlorohex-1-ene, undecenoic acid and 10-undecen-1-ol, etc.), generating polar hyperbranched oligomers. And the incorporation ratio of polar monomers could be adjusted by using different catalysts (0.1–1.0 mol%). The generated hyperbranched oligomer materials will exhibit some potential applications as lubricants or surface modifiers. Keywords Oxazole-based nickel catalysts Steric/electronic effect Hyperbranched ethylene oligomers Polar monomer Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction In recent decades, the discovery of late transition metal catalysts has promoted the rapid development of olefin polymerization field [1,2], and it will always be a frontier scientific problem in this field to affect the olefin polymerization process through the structural design of catalysts. Due to the low cost of nickel and its high abundance, nickel-based catalysts have shown great prospects in the application of olefin polymerization [3–13]. In 1978, the discovery of SHOP (Scheme 1 , I) catalyst has aroused widespread concern of researchers all over the world, which was notable for its high activity in producing α-olefins with Flory distribution [14–16]. The ethylene oligomers obtained by SHOP nickel catalysts have high-value as the base constituent of lubricants and the functional additives in surface modifiers [17]. Since then, the synthesis of ethylene oligomers via catalytic insertion reactions with nickel catalysts has been widely studied [18]. The nickel-based catalysts employed to produce ethylene oligomers are required to process strong β-H elimination reaction, on which small steric or electron-deficient substituents are generally installed [19–21]. The discovery of SHOP nickel catalyst marks the beginning of ethylene oligomerization catalyzed by late transition metal catalysts [22–24]. The polymers synthesized by SHOP nickel catalyst are linear and terminated with double bond [25]. Other phosphine-based nickel catalysts, such as phosphine-sulfonates nickel (Scheme 1, II) [26,27] and phosphine phosphonic amide nickel (Scheme 1, III) [28] can also catalyze ethylene oligomerization to prepare linear α-olefins. In contrast, some imino-based nickel catalysts can lead to highly branched polyethylene oligomers due to chain walking process via repeated sequences of β-H elimination and olefin reinsertion [29,30], such as iminopyridyl nickel catalysts (Scheme1, IV) [31–40] and salicylaldiminato nickel catalysts with small bulky substituent groups (Scheme 1, V) [41–43]. The hyperbranched ethylene oligomers may exhibit some potential applications as lubricants or surface modifiers. In this contribution, a series of nickel-based catalysts with oxazole structure were synthesized to produce hyperbranched ethylene oligomers (Scheme 2 ). All catalysts in this system could tailor hyperbranched ethylene oligomers through strong chain walking and chain transfer reaction simultaneously. The electronic and steric effect of these oxazole-based nickel catalysts were explored in ethylene polymerization. Furthermore, the copolymerization of ethylene with polar monomers was also catalyzed by these nickel catalysts to obtain polar hyperbranched oligomers. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Synthesis and characterization of the catalysts Methyl 2-(4-methoxyphenyl)-2-oxoacetate, methyl 2-oxo-2-(4-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl)acetate and methyl 2-(naphthalen-2-yl)-2-oxoacetate were synthesized according to the literature procedures [44]. The imino-based compounds (Imino-1-Imino-6) were prepared from the condensation reactions at 140 °C, which were obtained in 90–95% yields. The amide-based compounds (Amide-1-Amide-6) were synthesized by ammonolysis reactions in the presence of 2-amino-2-methyl-1-propanol, the yields of which were 45–53%. Subsequently, the oxazole-based ligands (L1-L6) were obtained in 90–95% yields from Robinson-Gabriel reactions at 80 °C for 40 h (Scheme 2). The compounds and ligands were characterized by 1H and 13C NMR analyses. The corresponding Ni complexes (Ni1-Ni6) were prepared in 74–90% yields by coordination reactions of the ligands with one equivalent of (DME)NiBr2 (DME = 1,2-dimethoxyethane) for 12 h. These nickel complexes were characterized by matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-fight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF-MS) and elemental analysis. The ligands L2, L3, L5 and complexes Ni2, Ni3, Ni5 were analyzed by infrared spectroscopy, indicating the formation of the desired nickel complexes (Figs. S1-S3). The molecular structures of Ni3, Ni4 and Ni6 complexes were determined by X-ray diffraction (Fig. 1 ). The nickel center adopted a distorted tetrahedron geometry, which is typical of previously reported α-diimine nickel complexes [45]. As shown in Fig. 1, the oxazole substituent group is insufficient to provide axial hindrance to the metal center, which may lead to a high rate of β-H elimination and a low molecular weight value. 2.2 Ethylene polymerization These nickel complexes were highly active towards ethylene polymerization (level of 106 g·mol−1·h−1), generating ethylene oligomers in this system. Firstly, different alkyl aluminum compounds were used as co-catalyst to study the catalytic performance, including Me2AlCl, MAO, EASC and Et2AlCl (Table 1 , entries 1–3 and 7). Considering the catalytic activities and economic benefits, Et2AlCl was chosen as co-catalyst in the following ethylene polymerization. In order to determine the molecular weight of generated oligomers accurately, the method of 1H NMR analysis was performed to calculate the ratio of relative integration from repeat unit and end-group protons. And the molecular weight of polymers calculated via 1H NMR analysis was used in the discussion of this work. Under 8 atm ethylene, Ni1 afforded ethylene oligomers at 20 °C with high activity (1.8 × 106 g·mol−1·h−1) and low molecular weight (1680 g·mol−1), while complex Ni2 led to higher activity (2.6 × 106 g·mol−1·h−1) and molecular weight (1750 g·mol−1). Unexpectedly, the sterically bulky complex Ni3 generated polymers with much lower activity (1.2 × 106 g·mol−1·h−1) and molecular weight (960 g·mol−1) compared to Ni1-Ni2 under the same condition (Table 1, entries 4, 7, 8). Under 8 atm ethylene, the branching density of oligomers catalyzed by Ni1-Ni3 at 20 °C followed the order: Ni1 (133/1000C) > Ni2(101/1000C) > Ni3(68/1000C). Detailed analysis and attribution of 13C NMR spectrum of the polyethylene catalyzed by Ni1 at 20 °C (Fig. 2 ) indicated that the oligomer is hyperbranched and rich in branching types, including methyl group (59/1000C), ethyl group (5/1000C), propyl group (3/1000C), n-butyl group (5/1000C), sec-butyl group (4/1000C) and long chain branching (16/1000C) approximately. The activities and molecular weight were increased as the ethylene pressure further increased to 30 atm, along with reducing branching density (Table 1, entries 11–13). In addition, internal double bonds were observed in the 1H NMR spectra of all oligomers in this system (Figs. S38-S64), which could be assigned to the chain walking mechanism. To further investigate the difference of catalytic performances of Ni1-Ni3, three model molecules Ni1+-Ni3+ (Fig. 3 ) representing catalytic active species of Ni1-Ni3 were studied by density functional theory (DFT) calculation [46–48]. Moreover, the steric maps of the optimized structures of Ni1+ -Ni3+ were generated by using the SambVca 2.1 A tool [49]. It was shown that the buried volumes of the nickel center follows the order: Ni3＋ (54.7%) > Ni2＋ (52.9%) > Ni1＋ (48.0%), suggesting that the steric effect inhibited the chain walking progress accounted for the differences in branching density presumably [50,51]. The DFT calculation results of ethylene coordination barrier showed the following order: Ni3+ (27.1 kJ/mol) > Ni1＋ (20.2 kJ/mol) ≈ Ni2＋ (19.8 kJ/mol), indicating that large steric hindrance could inhibit the coordination of ethylene, which led to lower activity and polymer molecular weight of Ni3 [52]. Moreover, the natural population analysis (NPA) charge value of Ni atom showed that the charge density of Ni center of Ni2+ with benzyl substituent was higher than that of Ni1+ . This effect may enhance the electrophilic activation of Ni center on ethylene monomer, resulting in higher catalytic activity and polymer molecular weight of Ni2 than Ni1 [53–55]. Ethylene polymerizations were catalyzed by Ni1 and Ni3 from 20 °C to 80 °C to reveal the influence of different temperature (Table 1, entries 4–6, 8–10). As the polymerization temperature increased, the activity of the two catalysts decreased significantly. It is proved in previous report that catalyst deactivation occurred at an elevated temperature [56]. The molecular weight of polyethylene products decreased in this system, which was ascribed to the increased rate of β-H elimination when increasing the polymerization temperature. In addition, the ethylene polymerization was employed for a prolonged time using complexes Ni1 and Ni3 at 80 °C to study the thermal stability (Fig. 4 ). As shown in Fig. 4, Ni1 may deactivated after 60 min and Ni3 remained its high performance up to 2 h. This phenomenon suggested that 2,6-diphenylmethyl substituted Ni3 possessed much better thermal stability than 2,6-diisopropyl substituted Ni1. Electronic effect of the ligand backbone structures was also investigated by conducting ethylene polymerization using Ni3-Ni5 (Table 1, entries 13–15). Compared to complex Ni3, complex Ni4 with electron‐donating group (OMe) was less active, while complex Ni5 with electron-withdrawing group (CF3) was more active towards ethylene oligomerization. This was mainly due to the increasing electrophilicity elevated the rate of ethylene coordination. The molecular weight of polyethylene products followed the order: Ni4 > Ni3 > Ni5, which was due to the enhanced chain transfer rate for the catalyst with electron-withdrawing group. The branching density of oligomers obtained by Ni3-Ni5 followed the order: Ni5 > Ni3 > Ni4 and this may be resulted from the enhanced chain walking along with the increased electrophilicity [57,58]. Compared to complex Ni3, complex Ni6 with naphthalene structure showed increased activity and branching density, producing ethylene oligomer with molecular weight 980 g·mol−1 (Table 1, entry 16). These results indicated that the catalytic performance of ethylene polymerization could be modulated by adjusting the electronic and steric effects of the catalysts. 2.3 Ethylene copolymerization with polar monomer These oxazole-based nickel complexes could also catalyze the copolymerization of ethylene with polar monomers to prepare functionalized hyperbranched oligomers. In the copolymerization of ethylene with 6-chlorohex-1-ene (Table 2 , entries 1–3), catalyst Ni1 showed a higher incorporation ratio of polar monomers than Ni2 and Ni3, because of the enhanced steric hindrance of these two catalysts. In contrast, Ni2 generated copolymer with a higher molecular weight than Ni1 with comonomer incorporation ratio of 0.8 mol%. Bio-renewable undecenoic acid comonomer was also selected for copolymerization investigations [59]. High activities (level of 105 g·mol−1·h−1) and moderate comonomer incorporation ratios (0.3–0.9 mol%) were observed in the copolymerization process. Ni1 produced the copolymer with the comonomer incorporation ratio (0.9 mol%) and low molecular weight (Table 2, entry 4). Ni2 led to the formation of a copolymer with increased activity, molecular weight and decreased incorporation ratio (0.8 mol%) (Table 2, entry 5). Ni3 showed the decreased activity and polymer molecular weight, along with decreased comonomer incorporation ratio (Table 2, entry 6). The incorporation ratio of copolymers produced by Ni3-Ni6 were very vicinal (Table 2, entries 6–9), which may be due to that the coordination of polar monomers is greatly affected by steric effect, but less affected by electronic effect. Furthermore, the copolymerization of ethylene and other types of polar monomers catalyzed by Ni2 complex were also provided in Table 2, including methyl 10-undecenoate (Table 2, entry 10, incorporation ratio: 0.1%) and 10-undecen-1-ol (Table 2, entry 11, incorporation ratio: 0.4%). 3 Conclusions In summary, a series of oxazole-based nickel complexes were prepared and characterized. With Et2AlCl as co-catalyst, all nickel complexes were active in ethylene polymerization generating the hyperbranched ethylene oligomers. The catalytic performance of ethylene polymerization could be modulated by adjusting the electronic and steric effects of the catalysts. DFT calculations were also performed to reveal the electronic and steric effects of the ligand structures. In addition, these nickel complexes could catalyze the copolymerization of ethylene and polar monomers (6-chlorohex-1-ene, undecenoic acid and 10-undecen-1-ol, etc.), affording polar hyperbranched oligomers. And the incorporation ratio of polar monomer could be adjusted by using different catalysts (0.1–1.0 mol%). Therefore, the structure designing of catalysts is always the key issue for olefin polymerization. And the study of these novel nickel complexes in this work will enrich the catalyst systems in olefin polymerization and may also inspire more applications in other catalytic areas. coredata.dc:description: Since the discovery of Shell-Higher-Olefin-Process (SHOP), ethylene oligomerization has been one of the most significant processes of homogenous transition-metal catalysts. And the structure designing of catalysts is always the key issue for ethylene oligomerization. In this contribution, a series of oxazole-based nickel complexes were synthesized to prepare the hyperbranched ethylene oligomers. The catalytic performance could be modulated by adjusting the electronic and steric effects of the nickel catalysts. And DFT calculations were also performed to reveal the electronic and steric effects of the ligand structures. Specially, these nickel complexes could catalyze the copolymerization of ethylene and polar monomers (6-chlorohex-1-ene, undecenoic acid and 10-undecen-1-ol, etc.), generating polar hyperbranched oligomers. And the incorporation ratio of polar monomers could be adjusted by using different catalysts (0.1–1.0 mol%). The generated hyperbranched oligomer materials will exhibit some potential applications as lubricants or surface modifiers.
coredata.dc:title: The synthesis of hyperbranched ethylene oligomers by nickel catalysts with oxazole structure
